Is systemic racism still racism?
Tom Handy
August 31
Engineer, Musician, Father, Husband, Christian
According to the good folks at the Oxford Dictionary, systemic means relating to a system, especially as opposed to a particular part. Racism is defined as prejudice, discrimination, or antagonism directed against a person or people on the basis of their membership of a particular racial or ethnic group, typically one that is a minority or marginalized. From this, we can say that systemic racism is a society-wide prejudice, discrimination, or antagonism directed against a person or people on the basis of their membership of a particular racial or ethnic group. This does not exist in the US. There is no society-wide racism neither in law nor societal norms. What's the difference between reverse racism and systemic racism?
Alan Browning
February 20, 2020
Software Developer
Logically speaking there's no such thing. But the term came in to being around the time of the Allan Bakke court case. He had applied to the University of California Davis Medical School and was denied admission. He filed suit against the school claiming that its affirmative action program was unconstitutional under the Fourteenth Amendment. The school had, in fact, reserved a certain number of openings in each class for minorities. So a minority applicant was competing for one spot out of 100 available, but a white applicant was competing for one spot out of 85 and therefore the odds of getting in (assuming the test scores qualified for entry) were lower. The Supreme Court ruled that race can be used in an admissions policy but that a quota is not allowed. So the term reverse racism is ge

What is the Definition of Systemic ? : Systemic Denotes : Of the whole body or concerning the whole body, not confined to a particular part. Of blood circulation other than pulmonary. Of an insecticide, fungicide, etc. entering the plant via the roots or shoots and passing through the tissues. In Linguistics, Systemic Denotes a Model of Functional Syntax developed by Halliday from the late 1950s . The basic idea is that any act of communication realizes a set of choices : thus, for example, the utterance of She went out' realizes, among others, the choice of a declarative structure. Each choice is at a certain level in a hierarchy of ranks, for example, the choice of declarative is at clause level. What is systemic about systemic racism?
Claire Jordan
July 1, 2020
Worked at National Health Service (NHS)
Note that systemic is not the same as systematic. As I understand it systemic racism is racism which has become built into the system, so that people dont have to be consciously racist for it to exist (although some are of course). For example, up until the 1960s black people in the US were often deliberately prevented from buying houses in nice areas, even if they could easily afford them, but were deliberately coralled into areas with poor houses and poor schools, which then reduced their chances of getting a good job. The United States of America  American with some background in American History.
Based only on incarceration rate, you would be making a logical fallacy. A current state of any kind only suggests possible causes, but does not confirm them. That means if the incarceration rate of Black Americans is proportionately higher than other groups, there may be one or more causes other than random chance - what they are though is not automatically racism. Consider these factors: * A higher percentage of violent crime occur in urban centers of large cities * A disproportionate number of crimes occur in urban centers with high unemployment and high poverty rate * Police are deployed in greater numbers where crime rates are the highest * Most people incarcerated were found guilty of the crimes they committed These facts are true in America.
